awd_titl_txt: Learning Through Collaborative Design: Professional Development to Foster Productive Epistemic Discourse in Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Florida State University will investigate the role of collaborative design in supporting teachers' professional growth around productive epistemic discourse in high school science classrooms. The project, Learning Through Collaborative Design Professional Development to Foster Productive Epistemic Discourse in Science, will examine an activity that is often used for the generation of curricular materials, collaborative design, and explore its promise in fostering biology teachers' professional growth as part of a larger professional development experience focused on epistemic practice.  It will establish epistemic discourse as both a means of communication and a learning outcome in high school biology classrooms.  The program goals are to understand the role of collaborative designs in shaping science teachers' learning about and enactment of instruction that fosters productive epistemic discourse in science, and to produce knowledge about teacher learning that can inform the design of professional development programs around productive epistemic discourse in science. The outcomes of this research will provide insight into teacher learning around a more robust understanding of science teaching, design principles essential in creating effective approaches to professional development, and a field tested professional development experience. Both the research and the teacher professional growth provided by project will involve a total of 70 teachers and their students.

This research project will include two cycles of design and development of the professional development experience. It will include mixed methods and a longitudinal examination of teacher and student learning fostered by professional development. The research for the first phase will be qualitative in nature and will result in a series of case studies that highlight different facets of the interactions that influence teachers' learning. Following this qualitative phase, through a field study that employs multivariate analysis of covariance and hierarchical linear models analytical techniques, the effectiveness of the design and development stages will be compared to an alternative professional development experience that is similar to the project's professional development but does not include collaborative design.

por.por_cntn:
When science lessons are framed as spaces for students to ‘figure things out’ they open up opportunities for students to build proficiency in science (NRC, 2012; Passmore, 2014). This supports that students’ learning is fostered through social sense-making. The project, entitled Learning through Collaborative Design Professional Development (LCD-PD), was designed to support teacher learning about practices that frame students’ classroom efforts as a process of ‘figuring out’ through productive epistemic talk- more colloquially termed ‘science talk.’ LCD-PD was designed to work to understand the role of a specific type of PD approach – teachers’ collaborative design of ambitious lessons – in providing teachers with the skills needed to engage students in productive science talk.

Project Goals

The goals of LCD-PD were to (1.) understand the role of collaborative design in shaping science teachers’ learning about and enactment of instruction that fosters productive science talk, and (2.) produce knowledge about teacher learning that can inform future design of professional development programs around productive science talk.

Phase 1:  PD Design

During Phase 1, a model of PD that supported the focus of this project was developed and refined to position teachers to collaboratively design, implement, analyze, and redesign lessons to support student science talk. Research from Phase 1 of the project is identifying effective PD ‘Science Talk’ design principles (i.e., attending to the kinds of PD activities employed, modeling effective practices to support talk, and maintaining a balance in activities that frame teachers’ PD work as engaging as a student and coupled with subsequent reflection as a teacher), key instructional components that maintain high-level student thinking (i.e., rigorous tasks and continual teacher talk moves that press students for thinking across the arc of a lesson), and the impact that framing and teacher moves have on student learning through talk. During Phase 1, the team designed, implemented, and refined the PD in two Discipline-Based Research cycles of redesignin two school districts in the South-eastern United States across two years. 

Phase 2:  The field test

During Phase 2, the field test compared the impact of the LCD-PD model to a Learning through Participation in Classroom Activity (LTP) PD model. Both the LCD and LTP models of PD supported teachers’ learning about the importance of and how to foster science talk through a six-day summer institute and in-school cycles of PD; however, only the LCD-PD summer and in-school cycles provided opportunities for teachers to collaborate with colleagues to redesign lessons with the goal of fostering students’ productive science talk. The LTP PD was the same except that the time devoted to collaborative design in the LCD model was devoted to experiencing Nature of Science Lessons (in order to keep the length of the PD equal for the two groups). The field test was conducted through offering each version of the professional development to a matched set of biology teachers drawn from two school districts in the Southeastern United States.  Teachers’ participation in the professional development and their classroom instruction was closely observed and student interactions and learning were documented. 

The Intellectual merit of the project focus extended what is known about science teacher learning around productive science talk and what is known about the optimal design of professional development experiences. Our work details that collaborative design:

a)     Is enhanced when teachers collaboratively work on similar, rigorous lessons that they have experienced as learners and then teach individually in their own classrooms;

b)    Begins in the professional development experience, but extends to other, less traditional and less structured, technology based, asynchronous interactions (e.g., Google Docs, texts);

c)     Is particularly needed when the instructional task to be taught is demanding for students and unfamiliar to teachers.

Our work speaks to the role of collaborative design of instructional materials in supporting teacher learning to enact ambitious instructional tasks in which students are positioned as sense-makers, leading to an increase in students’ biology learning. 

Additionally, our work sheds light on what is required for teachers to support students in their engagement in such talk.  We have identified that prolonged scientific sensemaking requires more than a rigorous task and interactions between teachers and students, but also requires interactions between social and affective characteristics and conceptions of sensemaking in science.

The Broader Impacts of the project are to impact society by the development and field testing of an professional development experience that supports high-school biology teachers in engaging their students in the “doing of science” through the design and enactment of rigorous science tasks that require students to learn science through talking science.  The identification of teacher collaborative design as an essential component of teacher professional development has the potential to contribute to increasing students' science learning more broadly.

References

National Research Council. (2012). A framework for K-12 science education. National Academies Press.

 Passmore, C. (November 10, 2014) NSTA Blog, https://www.nsta.org/blog/implementing-next-generation-science-standards-how-your-classroom-framed-important-what-you-do
